title: Alfred Riedl
text:
Alfred Riedl (2 November 1949 – 8 September 2020) was an Austrian <a href="Association%20football">football</a> player and <a href="coach%20%28sport%29">manager</a>. As a player he was a <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29">striker</a>. His last coaching role was with the <a href="Indonesia%20national%20football%20team">Indonesia national football team</a>.
Playing career.
Club career.
He first played for <a href="FK%20Austria%20Wien">FK Austria Wien</a>, before leaving Austria to play for the Belgian club <a href="K.%20Sint-Truidense%20V.V.">Sint-Truiden</a> at the age of 22. After he played eight seasons in <a href="Belgian%20First%20Division">Belgian First Division</a> (two with Sint-Truiden, two with <a href="R.%20Antwerp%20F.C.">Royal Antwerp</a> and four with <a href="Standard%20Li%C3%A8ge">Standard Liège</a>), Riedl enjoyed a brief spell at <a href="FC%20Metz">FC Metz</a> in France. He came back to Austria after a single season, to play for <a href="Grazer%20AK">Grazer AK</a>, and then at <a href="Wiener%20Sportclub">Wiener Sportclub</a> and <a href="VfB%20Admira%20Wacker%20M%C3%B6dling">VfB Admira Wacker Mödling</a>. He finished twice as <a href="Belgian%20First%20Division%20top%20scorers">top scorer</a> of the Belgian First Division.
International career.
Riedl was capped four times for the <a href="Austria%20national%20football%20team">Austria national football team</a>, making his debut in April 1975 against <a href="Hungary%20national%20football%20team">Hungary</a>.
Coaching career.
As a manager, Riedl has coached <a href="Olympique%20Khouribga">Olympique Khouribga</a> (Morocco, 1993–94), <a href="Al-Zamalek">Al-Zamalek</a> (Egypt, 1994–95), <a href="Al%20Salmiya%20Club">Al Salmiya</a> (Kuwait, 2001–03), and many national teams, including <a href="Austria%20national%20football%20team">Austria</a> (1990–92), <a href="Liechtenstein%20national%20football%20team">Liechtenstein</a> (1997–98), <a href="Palestine%20national%20football%20team">Palestine</a> (2004–05), <a href="Vietnam%20national%20football%20team">Vietnam</a> (1998–2001, 2003–04, 2005–07), and <a href="Laos%20national%20football%20team">Laos</a> (2009–10). In the <a href="2007%20AFC%20Asian%20Cup">2007 AFC Asian Cup</a>, he has coached Vietnam to a 2–0 victory over UAE and help the team to get to the quarterfinal for the first time in history. Unfortunately, in late 2007, after the team's disappointing performance in the <a href="SEA%20Games%202007">SEA Games 2007</a> competition, he was fired and replaced by the Portuguese coach <a href="Henrique%20Calisto">Henrique Calisto</a>. In October 2008, he returned to <a href="Vietnam">Vietnam</a> to coach the <a href="H%E1%BA%A3i%20Ph%C3%B2ng%20F.C.">Hải Phòng</a> soccer club. However, after only three matches with poor performance, he was dismissed. On 9 July 2009, he signed a contract as head coach of <a href="Laos%20national%20football%20team">Laos</a>, the contract was for two years.
Indonesia.
On 4 May 2010, Alfred Riedl was named the new coach of Indonesia's national and under-23 sides. He led the <a href="Indonesia%20national%20football%20team">Indonesian national team</a> to the <a href="AFF%20Suzuki%20Cup%202010%23Final">2010 AFF Suzuki Final</a> but lost to <a href="Malaysia%20national%20football%20team">Malaysia</a> on 2–4 aggregate score. Then suddenly, on 13 July 2011, he lost his job because of a "contract dispute", after a highly publicized political power struggle within the <a href="PSSI">Football Association of Indonesia</a> (PSSI), and was replaced by <a href="Wim%20Rijsbergen">Wim Rijsbergen</a>.
After a return to Laos as technical director and Belgian club <a href="C.S.%20Vis%C3%A9">Visé</a> as head of youth development, Riedl was reappointed as Indonesia national team head coach in December 2013, signing a 3-year contract. His contract was terminated by mutual consent at the end of 2014, after Indonesia failed to qualify for the knockout stages of the <a href="2014%20AFF%20Suzuki%20Cup">2014 AFF Suzuki Cup</a>. Riedl then accepted the head coach job of <a href="PSM%20Makassar">PSM Makassar</a> in early 2015, but resigned in April the same year because of health issues, before the league even started.
Rield returned as the head coach of Indonesia in 2016 on a one-year contract, and this time he guided Indonesia to the finals of <a href="2016%20AFF%20Suzuki%20Cup">2016 AFF Suzuki Cup</a>, repeating his 2010 performance. After Indonesia lost to Thailand 2–3 on aggregate in the finals, his contract was not renewed by PSSI.
Death.
Riedl died on 8 September 2020 in Austria due to cancer.
